name: Kepler-81
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-81 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-81 is a star with 0.4899999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.59 times its radius. It is located 1147.38 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-81 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-81 d

Kepler-81 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.84 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-81.

The mass of Kepler-81 d is 1.52 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-81 d is 1.21 that of Earth. At 1.52 Earth masses, Kepler-81 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-81, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
